questions.text: The following test is performed to assess:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B- This is pen test which checks function of abductor pollicis brevis We ask the patient to outstretch hand and then touch tip of the pen with the tip of the thumb. Therefore, it is used to assess function of abductor pollicis brevis which is supplied by median nerve.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of pain around the left hip joint following a road traffic accident. On examination, the affected limb was flexed, adducted and medially rotated with obvious shortening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-In anterior hip dislocation there is flexion, abduction and external rotation. Option B-Here, the affected limb is flexed, adducted and medially rotated so this points to posterior hip dislocation. Option C-Transcervical fracture is another name for fracture NOF,it presents with extended hip with lateral rotation of less than 45 degrees. Option D-Intertrochanteric fracture presents with extended hip with lateral rotation of more than 45 degrees.

choices.text: Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Traction, Palmar flexion, Ulnar deviations, POP
Traction, POP, Palmar Flexion, Ulnar deviation,
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Colle’s fracture occurs due to fall on outstretched hand and is characterised by impaction,radial tilt and dorsal tilt. sequence of correction isTraction, Palmar flexion, Ulnar deviations, POP Traction is given to reduce impaction of bony fragments into each other. then,palmar flexion is done to correct dorsal tilt of colle`s fracture. then,Ulnar deviation is done to correct the radial tilt. finally POP cast is applied.

choices.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction

questions.text: 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The first step in case of dislocation is reduction So we will go for closed reduction and assessment of hip stability. Option B-CT and 3D reconstruction are not required as first step is reduction of hip joint. Option C-High weight skeletal traction can be put after closed reduction is done. Option D-Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction is not the first step,it can be done if closed reduction fails.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in osteoporosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In osteoporosis,Calcium is normal and ALP is normal.

questions.text: Which of the following findings appear late in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Paralysis is typically a late sign of compartment syndrome, indicating severe nerve damage due to prolonged elevated pressure in the affected compartment. By the time paralysis occurs, irreversible ischemia and nerve injury have often taken place, making this a sign of a more advanced stage of compartment syndrome. Option A. Pallor: Pallor can appear early in compartment syndrome, as decreased blood flow causes the affected area to lose its normal color. It may happen before pulselessness or paralysis and is an important early indicator. Option B. Pulselessness: While pulselessness may occur in severe cases of compartment syndrome, it is not a reliable sign. In fact, pulse may still be palpable in early stages of compartment syndrome, and it is possible to have a pulse even with elevated compartment pressures. Thus, pulselessness should not be used alone for diagnosis. Option D. Pain on passive stretch: This is one of the earliest and most specific signs of compartment syndrome. The pain arises because of muscle ischemia when the muscles are stretched due to increased pressure in the compartment. It’s a critical finding for early detection and intervention.

choices.text: Spanning external fixator, fracture shaft tibia
Spanning external fixator, fracture shaft femur
Spanning external fixator, peri-articular fracture knee

questions.text: Identify the given device and the indication.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,C-Spanning external fixator and it is used for peri-articular fracture knee. Option D-Ilizarov retractor has multiple ring like components and it is used for distraction histogenesis for lengthening of bones.

questions.text: Identify the nerve injury and MC complication of this condition if left untreated. X-ray is given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It is a fracture of lateral condyle of humerus. m/c complication is lateral bony spur formation m/c complication requiring treatment is nonunion [cubitus valgus] m/c nerve injury: tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

questions.text: Femur Shaft fracture patient comes after 2 days of fracture. He is having dyspnea and tachypnea. What is the probabale diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The shaft of femur has yellow bone marrow which has a lot of fat, now this fat can circulate and can cause fat embolism.The fat can occlude the capillaries in lungs and tissues leading to dyspnea and tachypnea. Option B-Air embolism can occur after injury to venous structure like external jugular vein. Option C-Pulmonary hypertension is not related to fracture shaft of femur. Option D-Thromboembolism can occur due to DVT due to prolonged immobilisation but in the given case scenaria fat embolism is more likely a the shaft of femur has yellow bone marrow which has a lot of fat, now this fat can circulate and can cause fat embolism

questions.text: Antenatal USG showing multiple fractures of long bones. Which of the following is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Achondroplasia has short limbs but you won`t see deformity, diaphyseal fractures, different stages of healing. Option B-Marfan presents with hyperelasticity of joints and other structures. Option C-Here we can see deformity, diaphyseal fractures, different stages of healing-all of them clubbed together support diagnosis of Osteogenesis imperfecta.It is d/t collagen1A1 gene mutation because of which bone formation is not proper. Option D-Cretinism presents with infantile body proportion and not with deformity, diaphyseal fractures, different stages of healing

questions.text: A male child was brought in with previous history of URTI and Headache. He currently has fever, fatigue and pain on walking for which USG and joint fluid aspiration was done and antibiotics were given. The peripheral smear shows following finding. What is the most probable organism that can be isolated from the joint aspirate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-M/C cause of osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is salmonella. Option B-M/C cause of osteomyelitis overall is staphylococcus Option C,D-streptococcus and E.coli are less common causes of osteomyelitis

choices.text: Neurological Assessment-closed reduction- and again check neurological assessment -analgesic-cast

questions.text: Which will be the ideal treatment for distal radius fracture with Sharp ends at fracture site & soft tissue swelling was seen on wrist on X ray. What`s the further management ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) whenever we are, dealing with a fracture where there is a chance of neuro muscular injury, always assess the neurovascular injury first. Now, if we feel neuro vascular supply is intact, go for a closed reduction and then again check neurological assessment f/b analgesic and cast. Neurological Assessment-closed reduction- and again check neurological assessment -analgesic-cast

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is Finkelstein test done for De Quervain’s tenosynovitis of Ist extensor compartment of the wrist (APL & EPB).

questions.text: Identify the angle of scoliosis shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Kite`s angle is used in CTEV. Option B-Cobb’s angle is calculated to see the degree of scoliosis. Option C,D-Bohler’s angle and Gissane’s angle is used in fracture calcaneum.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is fish mouth spine/cod fish vertebra as there is biconcave appearance of vertebral bodies.Usually, it is seen in OsteoMalacia but here in the question,it is mentioned an old lady, therefore, osteoporosis is a better answer than osteomalacia. Option B-spondylolysis can occur due to fracture pedicle. Option C-spondylolisthesis is slippage of one vertebra with respect to other. Option D-fish mouth spine/cod fish vertebra is seen in OsteoMalacia

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Bisphosphonates are DOC for osteoporosis. Option B-Raloxifene is a SERM that can be used in postmenopausal female with osteoporosis but it`s not the DOC. Option C-Estrogen deficiency is a cause of postmenopausal osteoporosis but it`s not routinely used for this purpose. Option D-Combined OCPs are also not routinely used for this purpose.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated him by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, his arm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pulled elbow is distal subluxation of the head of radius d/t which radio-carpal joint widens up. This is c/a pulled elbow or nursemaid’s elbow.

questions.text: Identify the given sign ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Popeye’s sing represents Biceps tendon rupture-usually the long head of biceps gets torn and then the biceps resemble the biceps of cartoon character popeye. Option B-Inverted champagne bottle sign can be seen in charcot marie tooth disease.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints are classically involved in rheumatoid arthritis Option B-Osteoarthritis is the answer because Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC occurs in osteoarthritis while wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints are classically involved in rheumatoid arthritis. Option C-Psoriatic arthropathy has history of cutaneous and nail lesions of psoriasis with DIP involvement. Option D-Jaccoud arthropathy is a reversible deformity seen in diseases like SLE.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Lumbricals are involved in hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joint Option B-Palmar interossei = adduction of fingers(PAD) Option C-Dorsal interossei = abduction of fingers(DAB) Option D-Adductor pollicis performs adduction at thumb.

questions.text: A child was brought with bony deformities as shown in the radiograph below. It could be due to the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia. Option B-The given paediatric radiograph depicts the bowing of legs, which occurs due to rickets that results from the deficiency of Vitamin D that results in poor mineralisation of bone leading to rickets in children and osteomalacia is adults. Option C-Vitamin K deficiency results in bleeding disorders. Option D-Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The image shown above is that of a cock-up splint. It is used to manage radial nerve palsy. Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Option B-Median nerve injury causes carpal tunnel syndrome. Option C-knuckle bender splint is used in ulnar injury. Option D-Turn buckle splint is used in Volkmanns ischemic contracture

choices.text: Bipartite fracture patella, X-ray of the other knee
Fracture of upper pole of patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic knee pain but has no history of trauma. Identify the condition shown in the radiograph below and the appropriate management.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Patellar avulsion fracture do not have a smooth discontinuity. Option B-The given X ray shows a patella with a smooth discontinuity suggestive of an unfused accessory ossification center. Since this should arouse the suspicion of a bipartite patella, appropriate management would be to take an X ray of the other knee to confirm the same on other side. Option C,D-Fracture of upper pole of patella and Avulsion fracture also do not have a smooth discontinuity.

questions.text: A patient at the orthopedics OPD complains of troubled sleep at night due to numbness and tingling sensation involving his lateral 3 digits. His symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Which amongst the following options correctly describes his condition along with the test used to assess it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The clinical vignette is suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome which is the most common entrapment mononeuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel. Durkan’s test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan’s test, direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds, elicits paraesthesia and pain. Guyons canal syndrome is due to compression of ulnar nerve for which froment test can be done.

questions.text: A child is brought to the orthopedics OPD with a deformity in the lower limb and hyperpigmented skin lesions. The xray of her thigh is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Non-ossifying fibroma do not present with hyperpigmented skin lesions. Option B-The above Xray shows the bending of the femur known as Shepherd’s crook deformity. It is seen in fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur. Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterised by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is associated with Albright-McCune syndrome. Option C,D-Paget’s disease and Osteogenesis imperfecta do not present with hyperpigmented skin lesions.

questions.text: The given image is an xray of a 22-year-old female. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Chondroblastoma occurs in males of less than 18 years age. Option B-Osteochondroma presents as a bony stalk covered by a cartilaginous cap. Option C-The given X ray showing a lytic lesion at the end of a long bone with a soap bubble appearance suggests a giant cell tumor (GCT) or osteoclastoma. A GCT is a benign but locally aggressive tumor commonly occurring at the ends of long bones as a solitary lytic lesion in epiphysis. Option D-Aneurysmal bone cyst mimic GCT but occurs in a younger age group.

questions.text: What is this type of Amputation called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Below knee

questions.text: A child sustained an injury as shown in the below radiograph. What is the classification used and what is the grade?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gartland's classification, Type III. This is a radiograph of a pediatric supracondylar humerus fracture, which is an injury specifically classified by Gartland's classification. The image clearly shows a complete displacement of the distal humerus fragment relative to the proximal humerus, with no cortical contact between the two fragments. This complete displacement is the defining characteristic of a Gartland Type III fracture. Salter-Harris classification, while used for pediatric fractures, specifically applies to fractures involving the growth plate (physis), which is not the primary classification for this particular fracture pattern.

questions.text: The following device was used to fix the left proximal femur fracture. Identify the implant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dynamic Hip screw

questions.text: An 18 year old boy complains of fever, and pain in the lower limb. There is localized rise of temperature and tenderness in the region shown in the radiograph. ESR is raised. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Osteomyelitis. The clinical presentation of fever, localized pain, and tenderness in the lower limb, combined with a raised ESR, points towards an inflammatory or infectious process. The radiographic findings provide the definitive clue: the X-ray shows changes consistent with a bone infection, specifically sclerotic and lytic areas, along with a subperiosteal reaction. This combination is highly characteristic of osteomyelitis, which is an infection of the bone. In contrast, while Ewing's sarcoma and osteosarcoma can present with pain and fever, their X-ray appearances typically show more aggressive patterns like "onion skin" or "sunburst" reactions, respectively, which are not visible here. Therefore, the classic infectious and inflammatory signs, coupled with the specific radiographic changes, make osteomyelitis the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: 8-year-old child has fever with pain and swelling in mid-thigh. Xray Reveals Lamellated appearance and Codman's triangle. Histopathology shows small round cell tumor positive for MIC-2. The Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ewing's sarcoma Ewing's sarcoma is the correct diagnosis. The patient's young age and symptoms of fever with pain and swelling in a long bone are highly suggestive. Furthermore, the X-ray findings of a lamellated "onion-skin" appearance and Codman's triangle are classic radiological signs of this aggressive tumor. Finally, the histopathology provides the definitive confirmation: a small round cell tumor that is specifically positive for the immunohistochemical marker MIC-2 (CD99), which is the hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.

questions.text: A young lady after intense workout of lifting heavy weights, presents to you with a lower back ache involving right hip and radiating to right ankle. MRI shows the following finding. What nerve root is likely to get involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) L5

questions.text: A patient met with road traffic accident and complains of severe back ache. X-ray is as shown below. What fracture does the patient have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chance fracture

questions.text: A patient sustained a fracture of the base of the fifth metatarsal in left foot. He was advised below knee pop cast. How long should the cast be used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 6-8 weeks

questions.text: A fracture line passing through which of these will impair longitudinal growth of the bone.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epiphyseal plate

questions.text: A child fell while playing and a Cast was applied. On removal of the cast the following deformity was seen. What is the most likely injury to have caused this deformity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Supracondylar humerus fracture

questions.text: A 10 year old child fell down the stairs. X-ray was done. Identify the structure injured as marked in the X-ray.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tibial tuberosity

questions.text: A 56 year old woman presented with chronic lower back pain. CT of lower back shows the following findings. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Spondylolisthesis

questions.text: Patient presented with a twisting injury of the knee. No bony injury was noted. Identify the test being performed.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lachman's test

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with history of pathological fracture of neck of femur. She has elevated ALP and N-Telopeptide. Her DEXA scan confirmed a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Which of the following would be raised?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. It was corrected and X-ray was taken post correction. By which of the following mechanisms will healing occur?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary healing

questions.text: 10 year old child presents with painless limping. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation: The X-ray provided shows classic signs of Perthes disease (Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease), which is avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children.

questions.text: A male presents with chronic back pain and anterior uveitis for several months. On examination there is tenderness in SIJ. His initial xray was normal. What is the investigation of choice to make the diagnosis at the earliest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This patient presents with chronic back pain, anterior uveitis, and tenderness in the sacroiliac joint — classic features of axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA), especially ankylosing spondylitis (AS). However, his initial X-ray is normal, which is common in early disease. • MRI of the sacroiliac (SI) joints is the investigation of choice in early disease because it can detect active inflammation (bone marrow edema, synovitis, enthesitis) before structural changes become visible on X-ray. • MRI helps diagnose non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis (nr-axSpA), which may later progress to radiographic AS.

questions.text: 65 year old lady presents with chronic low back ache. Her X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: The X-ray shows loss of anterior vertebral body height (especially noticeable in the lower lumbar vertebra), which is characteristic of a wedge compression/crush fracture. This is a common finding in osteoporotic vertebral fractures, especially in elderly women. • The anterior wedge deformity and overall decrease in vertebral height seen here is typical of a crush/compression fracture, not degenerative or spondylotic changes. • This explains the chronic low back pain in a 65-year-old woman, where osteoporosis is a significant risk factor.

questions.text: 60-year-old man presents with generalised bod ache and increasing hat size. On examination, the bones are warm to touch. X-ray shows lytic areas in long bones. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation: The patient presents with generalized bone pain, increased hat size, and bones warm to touch, along with lytic lesions in long bones on X-ray — all of which are classic features of Paget's disease of bone (also known as osteitis deformans). Key features of Paget's disease: • Increased hat size ? due to skull thickening • Bone pain and deformities • Warmth over bones ? due to increased vascularity in affected areas • Lytic lesions (early stage), mixed lytic-sclerotic (later) • Commonly affects elderly men

questions.text: A child had fracture of leg on trivial trauma and splaying of maetaphysis. What is possible etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vitamin D deficiency Explanation: A child presenting with: • Fracture after trivial trauma • Splaying of metaphysis …is strongly suggestive of Vitamin D deficiency leading to rickets. In rickets, defective mineralization of growing bones leads to: • Bone fragility ? fractures on minimal trauma • Metaphyseal changes like splaying, cupping, and fraying • Other signs may include bowing of legs, rachitic rosary, and delayed milestones

questions.text: 20 year old man sustains eversion injury to his foot while playing football. Which ligament is injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: An eversion injury of the ankle (foot twisted outward) commonly results in damage to the medial ligament complex, known as the deltoid ligament. • The deltoid ligament is a strong, fan-shaped ligament on the medial (inner) side of the ankle. • It resists eversion (outward rolling) of the foot. • Although it's very strong and less commonly injured compared to lateral ligaments, forced eversion (like during a football injury) can tear it, especially if significant force is applied.

questions.text: Young male sustained mid shaft tibia fracture and was treated surgically. In the post operative period he developed severe pain in the leg. On examination there was swelling in the leg and diminished sensations. He had stretch pain. However, the dorsalis pedis pulse was intact. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: This patient is presenting with classic signs of acute compartment syndrome, a surgical emergency. The key findings pointing to this diagnosis include: • Severe pain out of proportion to injury • Swelling • Diminished sensation • Stretch pain (pain on passive movement of toes) • Intact distal pulses (compartment syndrome affects perfusion at capillary level, not large vessels initially) In acute compartment syndrome, the pressure within a closed muscle compartment increases, compromising circulation and nerve function. Pulses can be intact, so normal pulses do NOT rule it out.

questions.text: Young male had sustained fracture shaft of fem after RTA. He was treated with surgical fixation. After 2 days, he developed cute onset shortness of breath and rashes on the upper chest and confusion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation: This young male developed: • Fracture shaft of femur (long bone fracture) • Acute onset shortness of breath • Petechial rash over upper chest • Confusion (neurological symptoms) ...2 days post-injury These findings are classic for Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES), a known complication following long bone fractures, especially femur and pelvis. Classic triad of FES: 1. Respiratory distress 2. Neurological symptoms (confusion, agitation, seizures) 3. Petechial rash (typically over chest, axilla, conjunctiva) FES typically develops within 24–72 hours after trauma or orthopedic surgery.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with knee pain xray show changes of arthritis. Synovial fluid analysis rhomboid crystals which were positively birefringent. What is diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation: The key findings in this case: • Elderly patient with knee pain • X-ray changes suggestive of arthritis • Synovial fluid shows rhomboid-shaped crystals • Crystals are positively birefringent under polarized light These are classic features of pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) deposition disease. • Pseudogout commonly affects large joints, especially the knee. • Crystals seen are rhomboid in shape and show positive birefringence under polarized light microscopy. • X-rays may show chondrocalcinosis (calcification of cartilage).
